awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Principal Component Analysis over Tree Spaces and Its Applications to Phylogenomics
awd_abstract_narration:
Phylogenomics is a relatively new field that seeks to understand evolutionary relationships between organisms at the scale of the whole genome. One of the central questions in evolutionary biology is a better understanding of the relationships between organisms, usually summarized in the form of a phylogenetic tree. The methods in common use for developing these trees tend to work best for closely related organisms, and when the sequences are relatively short; for example, the DNA sequence for a single gene applied to a collection of mammals. When comparing more distantly related organisms, or data from large portions of the genome, current techniques can break down. Since modern technology can quickly and cheaply produce genome-scale sequence data, there is a pressing need for better analytical tools tailored to this large-scale high-dimensional data. The most popular statistical methods for finding general patterns in large-scale data, such as Principal Component Analysis (PCA), make the assumption that the space where the data lies is flat, like the plane geometry of Euclid. However, the space of possible phylogenetic trees has a decidedly non-Euclidean geometry, with a surface more akin to an origami figure made with a sheet of rubber. The goal of this project is to develop alternative types of principal components, and methods to calculate them, which take into account the unusual structural features of the mathematical space of phylogenetic trees.


PCA is a statistical method that takes data points in a high dimensional Euclidean space into a lower dimensional plane which minimizes the sum of squares between each point in the data set and their orthogonal projection onto the plane. It has been used for clustering high dimensional data points for statistical analysis and it is one of the simplest and most robust ways of doing dimensionality reduction in a Euclidean vector space.  However, it assumes the properties of a Euclidean vector space. The space of all possible phylogenies on a fixed set of species does not form a Euclidean vector space, so PCA must be reformulated in the geometry of a tree-space. Motivated by the previous work by T. Nye in 2011 on construction of the first principal component, or principal geodesic, the PIs propose two geometric objects under different metrics which represent a k-th order principal component: (1) the locus of the weighted Frechet mean of k+1 points in a tree-space, where the weights vary over the associated probability simplex, under the Billera-Holmes-Vogtman (BHV) metric and (2) the tropical convex hull of k+1 points in a tree-space via the tropical metric in tropical geometry known as the max-plus algebra. The first aim of this project is to prove properties of the PCA under the BHV metric and the PCA under the tropical metric over tree-spaces. Then, the second aim is to develop efficient algorithms to compute/approximate them. Simulation studies will be conducted to show these algorithms perform well.  Then the PIs will apply these algorithms to empirical data sets, such as Apicomplexa, a phylum of parasitic alveolates including malaria, and African coelacanth genomes, and sequences of hemagglutinin for influenza from New York. The broader impact will include advising undergraduate students for the implementation of the algorithms and user interfaces of the software products. These research experiences will complement a new Data Science program being developed as a component of the current Hawaii EPSCoR program. A portion of the summer effort will also be used to collaborate with nearby high school science and engineering programs in the development of data analysis lesson modules.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to further investigate the statistical properties of a new class of phylogenetic data summarization techniques based on concepts found in traditional Principal Component Analysis techniques. Furthermore, we aimed to provide educational outreach opportunities to students on Hawaii island in areas related to phylogenetics specifically, and data science and statistics more generally. 

 

While the main planned program activities were significantly impacted by issues related to the COVID-19 epidemic, radically restricting the modalities with which activities could be offered, this also presented opportunities to redirect participant efforts into development of computational infrastructure and teaching resources that could be applied in the new online-focused environment. Project personnel participated in the development of multiple new courses for delivery online over the course of the grant, as well as the final stages of implementation of a new Bachelor’s degree program in Data Science. The degree program is the first of its sort offered by the University of Hawaii System of universities and colleges, and fills an important gap in the educational options available to Hawaii students at the tertiary level. 

 

Project personnel have also contributed to the development of open source teaching materials and software for online and in-person instruction in statistical programming, data science, and other fields. These software resources include integrations with the teaching resource Github Classroom, providing access to computer-assisted grading of statistical programming assignments and introducing students to a code management system widely used in modern industry. Other products include a free plugin for the Miro cloud-based whiteboard application, providing a LaTeX integration useful for mathematical instruction into that ecosystem. These software and educational resources have been released for free public access under open source licenses.

 

Additionally, project members have worked with instructors and researchers in several departments to transition educational and data analysis computational infrastructure from on-site hardware to cloud-based hosting options, including the NSF-funded Jetstream 2 cloud. Cloud-based Integrated Development Environment software that we have configured and managed has been used by students in over a dozen courses and multiple instructors across at least four academic departments at the University of Hawaii at Hilo. We have provided training and expert support for one significant campus lab to transition their machine learning training operations from a single on-site consumer gaming GPU to cloud-based machine-learning specialized GPU hardware, greatly expanding their ability to process and analyze data.

 

Students mentored by project members have completed undergraduate capstone and master’s thesis projects containing significant data-science and statistics applications. Although the original science goals related to further development of Principal Component Analysis in the space of phylogenetic trees did not yield promising further progress or generate significant student interest, there have been significant broader impacts of project member activities to campus computational and instructional resources that promise to continue to generate interest in statistical and data science tools from students, researchers, and instructional staff. These tools will support modernized education delivery and contribute to research activities across the university and beyond.
